Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental and Theoretical Studies of the Biomechanics of Fibrin Polymer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: These Collaborative awards by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Pennsylvania and University of Massachusetts at Lowell are to investigate the mechanical behavior of the structural component of blood clots, the fibrin gel. Long-term goal project is to modify fibrin to create distinctive new biomaterials for cell and drug delivery, patterning, and tissue engineering. With this award, the researchers will study the mechanical properties of fibrin clots at the macroscopic, microscopic and submolecular levels to understand the basis of their functional behavior. A key novelty of this work is combined state-of-the-art experimental and theoretical exploration to understand the mechanical behavior of fibrin networks at these different spatial scales. This research will provide opportunities for training of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students in the highly interdisciplinary areas of nanotechnology and biophysics, with attention to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. The scientific community will be reached by organizing symposia in international conferences, and by presenting research findings regularly, as well as the NSF-funded Nano/Bio Interface Center for NanoDay and other activities targeted at minority students and teachers in nearby high schools.

Technical: The research objective of this proposal is to understand the mechanical behavior of fibrin gels with the long-term goal of modifying fibrin to create distinctive new biomaterials for cell and drug delivery, patterning, and tissue engineering. Earlier studies by the researchers have demonstrated that the remarkable extensibility of fibrin clots has its origins in the unfolding of particular domains of the fibrin molecule, with the stress-strain response of an individual fiber connected to the force-stretch dependence at the nanoscale. Researchers plan to define the molecular structural and thermodynamic basis of fibrin deformability and viscoelasticity. A key novelty of this work is combined experimental and theoretical exploration to understand the tensile behavior of fibrin networks at different spatial scales, from submolecular (atomic) to macroscopic levels. This goal will be achieved by combining state-of-the-art experimental methodology with novel Molecular Dynamics simulations and a comprehensive continuum mechanics model. This research will provide opportunities for training of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students in the highly interdisciplinary areas of nanotechnology and biophysics, with attention to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. The scientific findings will be disseminated by organizing symposia in both national and international levels. The research findings will be presented to the community by attending other scientific meetings, as well as the NSF-funded Nano/Bio Interface Center for NanoDay and other activities targeting minority students and teachers in high schools.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main research objective of this project was to understand the mechanical behavior of blood clots (fibrin) from the molecular to the macroscopic length scales. Fibrin is the main component of blood clots and thrombi which have immediate relevance to human health. Therefore, an understanding of their mechanical behavior has the potential to shed light on how to prevent thrombi (which can cause heart attacks and strokes) and also help to design fibrin scaffolds which are used for tissue regeneration and repair. The project combined experimental, computational and analytical techniques to connect the mechanical behavior of fibrin at the molecular scale to its properties at the macroscopic scale. We list some of our major achievements below.

Intellectual merit: It had been known from before that a few centimeter long crosslinked fibrin clots could be stretched to more than three times their original length due to the forced unfolding of fibrin monomers at the molecular scale. One of the key regions of the fibrin molecule is a `coiled-coil? which is like two helices winding around each other. We showed in this project that the forced unfolding of this coiled-coil which causes it to become a ribbon-like beta-sheet under large tensile forces can be treated as a phase transition. The character of this phase transition is much like the phase transition that converts steam to water at high pressures. Furthermore, even though the phase transition occurs at the level of a single molecule whose dimension is a few nanometers, we can treat it mathematically as if a macroscopic bar under tension is changing phase. Such an analytical treatment results in enormous savings in computational time and it also affords a clear understanding of the physics of molecular stretching. Another important finding of this project was that fibrin clots at the macroscopic scales of a few centimeters behave like a foam under compression. Just like a foam is a porous solid with air in the pores, a fibrin clot is a random network of fibers with serum (mostly water) in its pores. When the fibrin clot is compressed the serum leaks out, when it is decompressed the serum is sucked back in. The fibers of the clots buckle and collapse on themselves making a dense phase with a large number of contacts, just as happens when a polymer foam is compressed. In fact, just as interfaces between densified and rarefied regions of a compressed foam can be easily seen in experiments, we showed that interfaces between densified and rarefied regions of a fibrin clot can be visualized. What?s more these interfaces can be seen to move as more compression is steadily applied to the fibrin clots. These insights can be combined in a continuum theory that allows us to describe and predict the compression response of fibrin clots. This is likely to be important in the analysis of how the forces imposed by a catheter affect a thrombus inside a blood vessel.

Broader impacts: Our experimental, computational and analytical techniques have laid a strong foundation for the study of more complex deformations of fibrin gels and blood clots both at the molecular and macroscopic length scales. We are building on this foundation to determine the compressive behavior of emboli extracted from patients in the hopes that a knowledge of the mechanical properties of thrombi will help in ameliorating the effects of diseases that helped cause them.

In related research, we have determined the structure of clotting factor XIII, studied the bonds that strengthen clots, the activation and fate of platelets, fibrinolysis, clot contraction, and detailed structures in early stages of clotting. We have also made discoveries and published papers on clot structure related to various diseases, such as venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, systemic lupus erythrematosis, heparin induced thrombocytopenia, and hemostatic disorders in pregnancy loss.

At a more practical level, funds from this project enabled the partial support of two post-doctoral fellows in John Weisel?s group, who presented their results at meetings and published their results, as listed. This grant also supported the training of two PhD students in the group of the co-PI, Prashant K. Purohit. One of these students graduated in 2017 after publishing five papers in academic journals and also attended several conferences to present his work. The second student will finish with a PhD by the end of this year and has also published in scholarly journals and spoken at conferences. Both these students have an excellent knowledge of biophysics/biomechanics even though they obtained all their degrees in mechanical engineering. This is significant because interdisciplinary research is becoming more the norm rather than the exception.


Last Modified: 08/16/2019
Modified by: John W Weisel

Fibrin is the main component of blood clots and thrombi which have immediate relevance to human health. Therefore, an understanding of their mechanical behavior has the potential to shed light on how to prevent thrombi (which can cause heart attacks and strokes) and also help to design fibrin scaffolds which are used for tissue regeneration and repair. The project combined experimental, computational and analytical techniques to connect the mechanical behavior of fibrin at the molecular scale to its properties at the macroscopic scale. We list some of our major achievements below. One of these students graduated in 2017 after publishing five papers in academic journals and also attended several conferences to present his work. The second student will finish with a PhD by the end of this year and has also published in scholarly journals and spoken at conferences. Both these students have an excellent knowledge of biophysics/biomechanics even though they obtained all their degrees in mechanical engineering. This is significant because interdisciplinary research is becoming more the norm rather than the exception. Last Modified: 08/16/2019 Submitted by: John W Weisel
